image.altText: Sharon Harrison kneels on the grass in her yard to show the flood damage on her property.

items.synopsis: Sharon Harrison says her property has been flooding ever since her neighbour did work on his driveway. She's spent almost three years waiting for a hearing in Victoria's civil tribunal.

title.children: As wait times at Victoria's civil tribunal blow out, lawyers say some people are 'giving up'

image.altText: A young girl wearing a hoodie looks at the camera with teary eyes and dirt on her face, other people in the background

items.synopsis: The Israeli military says it is launching a "precise and targeted operation" inside Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital. Follow live.

title.children: Israel says it is launching a military 'operation' inside Al-Shifa Hospital

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's what the Israeli military has said about the operation inside Al-Shifa Hospital on social media: IDF says the operation was preceded by "an effort to evacuate the hospital from the sick and homeless" IDF claims "hospital management was informed ahead of time about the entrance to the compound" While the operation continues, IDF claims "incubators, medical equipment and baby food" will be transferred to Al-Shifa The ABC could not immediately verify these claims. We will continue to update with further information as it comes to light.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's what Israel's military is saying about the operation so far

children.content: Here's what the Israeli military has said about the operation inside Al-Shifa Hospital on social media:
IDF says the operation was preceded by "an effort to evacuate the hospital from the sick and homeless"
IDF claims "hospital management was informed ahead of time about the entrance to the compound"
While the operation continues, IDF claims "incubators, medical equipment and baby food" will be transferred to Al-Shifa
The ABC could not immediately verify these claims.
We will continue to update with further information as it comes to light.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israel Defense Forces have said they are carrying out a "precise and targeted operation against Hamas in a specified area in the Shifa Hospital". They are basing the operation on "intelligence information and an operational necessity", the IDF said in a post on X. The IDF did not specify what that intelligence information is. Gaza Health Ministry spokesperson Ashraf Al-Qidra had earlier told Al Jazeera that Israel "informed us that it will raid Al-Shifa hospital complex in the coming minutes". Al-Qidra said Gaza officials had informed the International Committee of the Red Cross about Israel's warning. "The 'Israeli' occupation army recently informed the Ministry of Health of its intention to storm the Shifa Medical Complex after several days of besieging it and shooting everything that moves inside it", the Hamas media office said in a post in Arabic on Telegram. "We hold the occupation, the international community, and the United States of America fully responsible for the safety of thousands of medical staff, the wounded, and the displaced inside it. We warn against committing a massacre in the hospital." There has been no comment from the US. The White House had said earlier that it had its own intelligence that Hamas was using Gaza's largest hospital Al-Shifa to run its military operations, and probably to store weapons, saying those actions constituted a war crime. The information comes from a variety of intelligence methods, US national security spokesperson John Kirby said, without specifying the methods or the information.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it is carrying out an operation in a 'specific area' of Al-Shifa hospital

children.content: The Israel Defense Forces have said they are carrying out a "precise and targeted operation against Hamas in a specified area in the Shifa Hospital".
They are basing the operation on "intelligence information and an operational necessity", the IDF said in a post on X.
The IDF did not specify what that intelligence information is.
Gaza Health Ministry spokesperson Ashraf Al-Qidra had earlier
told Al Jazeera
that Israel "informed us that it will raid Al-Shifa hospital complex in the coming minutes".
Al-Qidra said Gaza officials had informed the International Committee of the Red Cross about Israel's warning.

"The 'Israeli' occupation army recently informed the Ministry of Health of its intention to storm the Shifa Medical Complex after several days of besieging it and shooting everything that moves inside it", the Hamas media office said in a post in Arabic on Telegram.

"We hold the occupation, the international community, and the United States of America fully responsible for the safety of thousands of medical staff, the wounded, and the displaced inside it. We warn against committing a massacre in the hospital."
There has been no comment from the US.

The White House had said earlier that it had its own intelligence that Hamas was using Gaza's largest hospital Al-Shifa to run its military operations, and probably to store weapons, saying those actions constituted a war crime.
The information comes from a variety of intelligence methods, US national security spokesperson John Kirby said, without specifying the methods or the information.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Heavy rain in Gaza has brought new concerns and challenges for Palestinians, many of whom are homeless and living in makeshift tents after weeks of Israeli bombardment. The start of the rainy season and the possibility of flooding increased fears that the densely populated enclave's sewage system will be overwhelmed and disease will spread. At a UN shelter in Khan Younis in southern Gaza, the rain brought dismay for displaced people who woke to find the clothes they put out to dry the night before had been drenched by rain. "We were in a house built of concrete and now we are in a tent," said Fayeza Srour, who fled to southern Gaza to escape bombardment in the north. "The nylon tarps, the tent and the wood will not resist any flooding … People sleeping on the floor, what will they do? Where will they go?" Winters can be wet and cold in Gaza, and the enclave is sometimes hit by flooding. The World Health Organization (WHO) said last week that Gaza faced an increased risk of disease spreading because Israeli air bombardments had disrupted the health system, limited access to clean water and caused people to crowd in shelters. There are already more than 30,000 cases of diarrhoea in a period where the WHO would normally expect 2,000 cases, WHO spokesperson Margaret Harris said in Geneva. "We've got so much infrastructural damage. We've got a lack of clean water. We've got people very, very crowded together. This is another reason why we are begging for a ceasefire to happen now," she said. Ahmed Bayram, a spokesperson for the Norwegian Refugee Council, said the heavy rain would impede the movement of people and rescue teams. "It will make it harder to save people stuck under the rubble, or to bury the dead, all of this amidst ceaseless bombardment and a fuel shortage catastrophe", he said. Facing the daunting scale of the humanitarian needs of Gaza's 2.3 million people, aid organisations have been unable to plan for the challenges posed by rain and flooding. Juliette Touma, Director of Communications at the UN Palestinian refugee agency (UNRWA), said the organisation was focused on meeting the population's needs "here and now." "We're barely able to make it from one hour to the next ourselves, because the situation on the ground is so, so, so desperate," she said. The rain brought relief for some displaced Palestinians in the central Gaza Strip town of Deir Al-Balah who had not been able to drink clean and fresh water in the past weeks. Some placed plastic buckets outside their tents to gather rainwater to drink. "We have been drinking salty water for 30 days. There has been no fresh water. I have just collected this from the rainwater," said Um Mohammad Shahin. Over 1.5 million people in Gaza are estimated to be internally displaced, including about 778,000 people who are staying in at least 154 UNRWA shelters, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fears of disease outbreaks as Gaza's displaced people are pummelled with heavy rain

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket is off to a better than expected start this morning. The ASX 200 index was up 113 points or 1.6%, at 7,119 points by 10:30am AEDT, with real estate (+3.4%) and mining (+2.8%) sectors leading the gains. However, the energy (-0.6%) sector was down. Biggest gains: Centuria Capital +8.3% to $1.37 Pilbara Minerals +7.7% to $3.78 Allkem +7.5% to $9.27 Charter Hall +6.8% to $10.65 Mineral Resources +6.6% to $63.76 Biggest losses: Karoon Energy -10.4% to $2.15 Computershare -3.6% to $23.88 QBE -1.8% to $15.43 Paladin Energy -1.3% to $0.96 Santos -1.2% to $7.19
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens sharply higher

However, the energy (-0.6%)
sector was down.
Biggest gains:
Centuria Capital
Pilbara Minerals
Allkem +7.5% to $9.27

Biggest losses:

Computershare

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By senior business correspondent Peter Ryan Optus has revealed its Singapore-based owner Singtel as the culprit in last Wednesday's outage. A spokesperson told the ABC that third parties aren't usually named but they confirm the SingTel Internet exchange known as STiX is to blame for sending changes to routing information that triggered the Optus crash — a meltdown that badly damaged the Optus reputation and it's now drawn Singtel into the spotlight. It comes after a report from the Sydney Morning Herald quoting an unnamed insider that its parent company in Singapore might be responsible. Optus initially declined to comment. Meanwhile, the IT resilience firm Cohesity warns many Australian companies are unprepared for cyberattacks. Click the link below for the full story from Peter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus confirms its Singapore parent Singtel responsible for outage

children.content: By senior business correspondent
Peter Ryan
Optus has revealed its Singapore-based owner Singtel as the culprit in last Wednesday's outage.

A spokesperson told the ABC that third parties aren't usually named but they confirm the SingTel Internet exchange known as STiX is to blame for sending changes to routing information that triggered the Optus crash — a meltdown that badly damaged the Optus reputation and it's now drawn Singtel into the spotlight.
It comes after a report from the Sydney Morning Herald quoting an unnamed insider that its parent company in Singapore might be responsible. Optus initially declined to comment.
Meanwhile, the IT resilience firm Cohesity warns many Australian companies are unprepared for cyberattacks.
Click the link below for the full story from Peter.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB is pencilling in a quarter on quarter rise of 1.5%, which is above the Reserve Bank’s implied pick of about 1.3-1.4%. Senior economist Taylor Nugent at NAB said in a note that one-off increase to award salaries in some sectors means the quarterly growth rate will be high and shouldn’t be extrapolated. "The high award wage increase does in part reflect labour market conditions but provides a higher increase than what non-award wages are seeing and will be lower next year," he said. "A 15% level adjustment for more than 250,000 aged care workers does not reflect conditions in the macro backdrop. "We think Wage Price Index will be back around 0.9% quarter on quarter in Q4." According to a Reuters poll, the market consensus for the September quarter wage growth is at 1.3%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What to expect from the third-quarter wage price index

children.content: NAB is pencilling in a quarter on quarter rise of 1.5%, which is above the Reserve Bank’s implied pick of about 1.3-1.4%.
Senior economist
Taylor Nugent at NAB said in a note that one-off increase to award salaries in some sectors means the quarterly growth rate will be high and shouldn’t be extrapolated.
"The high award wage increase does in part reflect labour market conditions but provides a higher increase than what non-award wages are seeing and will be lower next year," he said.
"A 15% level adjustment for more than 250,000 aged care workers does not reflect conditions in the macro backdrop.
"We think Wage Price Index will be back around 0.9% quarter on quarter in Q4."
According to a Reuters poll, the market consensus for the September quarter wage growth is at 1.3%.
